Correct|url=http://www.ndtv.com/opinion/on-ins-kolkata-pm-is-only-partially-correct-654566|accessdate=8 March 2015|agency=NDTV|date=16 August 2014|quote=At the moment, she is designed to carry only 32 Barak surface-to-air missiles...}}</ref><ref name=navaltechnology /> *[[Barak 8 (missile)|Barak 8]] missiles (''Range'': {{convert|0.5|km|mi|abbr=on}} to {{convert|90|km|mi|abbr=on}}<ref name=IHSJanesBarak82015>{{cite news|title=India commissions second Kolkata-class destroyer|url=http://www.janes.com/article/54950/india-commissions-second-kolkata-class-destroyer|accessdate=30 December 2015|agency=IHSJanes|publisher=janes|date=29 September 2015}}</ref>) *''Anti-ship/Land-attack missiles:'' *2 × 8-cell UVLM for 16 [[BrahMos]] anti-ship and land-attack missiles<ref name=navaltechnology /><ref name="Kolkata-class destroyer"/> *''Guns:'' *1 × [[OTO Melara 76 mm|76 mm gun Oto Melara SRGM]] *4 × [[AK-630]] [[Close-in weapon system|CIWS]] *''Anti-submarine warfare:'' *4 × 533 mm Torpedo tubes *2 × [[RBU-6000]] anti-submarine rocket launchers |Ship armour= |Ship armor= |Ship aircraft= 2 × Sea King or HAL Dhruv helicopters |Ship aircraft facilities=*[[Flight deck]] *Dual Enclosed [[hangar]] for a combination of 2 Seaking, Chetak or Dhruv helicopters |Ship notes= }} |}
The '''''Kolkata'' class''' (Project 15A) are a class of [[Stealth ship|stealth]] [[guided missile destroyer]]s<ref name=stealth>[http://www.naval-technology.com/projects/kolkata-class-guided-missile-destroyers/ Kolkata Class Guided Missile Destroyers - Naval Technology<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> constructed for the [[Indian Navy]]. The class comprises three ships – ''Kolkata'', ''Kochi'' and ''Chennai'', all of which are being built by [[Mazagon Dock Limited]] (MDL) in India, and are the largest destroyers to be operated by the Indian Navy. Due to delays in their construction, and a problem found during the sea trials, the initial commissioning date of the first ship of the class had been pushed back from 2010 to 2014.<ref name=it10j13>{{cite news|title=Navy's ongoing hunt for heavy torpedoes leads to delay in modernisation process|url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/indian-navy-hits-modernisation-crisis-no-weapons-tarpedoes/1/279309.html|accessdate=20 July 2013|newspaper=India Today|date=10 June 2013}}</ref>
The destroyers are a follow-on of the Project 15 {{sclass-|Delhi|destroyer|2}}s, but are considerably more capable due to major improvements in the design, the addition of substantial land-attack capabilities, and the fitting-out of modern sensors and weapons systems.<ref>{{cite book|author1=Toshi Yoshihara|author2= James Holmes|title=Strategy in the second nuclear age : power, ambition, and the ultimate weapon|publisher=Georgetown University Press|location=Washington, DC|isbn=1589019288|page=143|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hpFJflNJJmsC&pg=PA143&dq=kolkata+class+destroyer&hl=en&sa=X&ei=RrrsUco_zuKsB5PpgSA&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=kolkata%20class%20destroyer&f=false|editor= James R. Holmes}}</ref>
==Development== {{See also|Delhi-class destroyer}}
In 1986, the Cabinet Committee on Political Affairs (CCPA) approved a follow-on class of the earlier Project 15 ''Delhi''-class destroyers. The aim was that the follow-on class would incorporate a higher level of air-defence, land attack, anti-submarine and anti-ship capabilities than the preceding class. However, the [[Indian Navy]] did not initially take up the option.<ref name="Kolkata-class destroyer">[http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/world/india/d-project-15a.htm Kolkata-class destroyer] GlobalSecurity.org</ref> By the year 2000, the Indian Navy had redesigned the follow-on ''Kolkata'' class to incorporate even higher levels of technology (including modern stealth characteristics) and in May of that year, approval for the construction was given. Concept and function for Project 15A was framed by the navy's Directorate of Naval Design, while the detailed design was developed by [[Mazagon Dock Limited]] (MDL).<ref name=bs-20080415>{{cite web|author=Indian Navy: Global & Local - I |url=http://www.business-standard.com/india/storypage.php?autono=320123 |title=World-class warships at Indian prices |publisher=Business-standard.com |date=15 April 2008 |accessdate=2 April 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hindu.com/2003/09/27/stories/2003092702901200.htm |title=Mazagon Dock lays keel of destroyer |publisher=Hindu.com |date=27 September 2003 |accessdate=2 April 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mdlindia.com/annual_report/Directors%20Report%202005-06_231106.pdf |title=Mazagon Dock Annual Report |publisher=Mdlindia.com |accessdate=2 April 2010}}</ref>
===Construction=== [[File:P-15A Kolkata class hull unit.jpg|thumb|left|Hull of a 15A destroyer being built at Mazagon Docks.]]
Construction of three ''Kolkata''-class ships was sanctioned by the [[Government of India]] in May 2000, and steel for the lead ship was cut in March 2003.<ref name=navaltechnology>{{cite web|title=Kolkata Class Guided Missile Destroyers, India|url=http://www.naval-technology.com/projects/Kolkata-class-guided-missile-destroyers/|publisher=Naval Technology|accessdate=15 June 2013}}</ref> Construction began in September 2003 at Mazagon Docks, Mumbai, with an initial expectation that the first of the class would be handed over to the navy by 2010. However, since then the ''Kolkata'' class has suffered consecutive delays, slow construction procedures and technical problems which saw the first ship of the class enter service during mid 2014. The delays in the construction programme have been attributed to persistent design changes made by the Indian Navy to incorporate new weapons systems and sensors, failure by a [[Ukraine|Ukrainian]] shipyard to deliver the ship's propellers and shafts and the contract later being awarded to a [[Russia]]n firm,<ref name=bs-20090401>{{cite web|url=http://www.business-standard.com/india/news/russia-steps-in-to-bail-out-sinking-project-15-a/353555/ |title=Russia steps in to bail out sinking Project 15-A |publisher=Business-standard.com |date=1 April 2009 |accessdate=2 April 2010}}</ref> and finally the delay in the delivery of the [[Barak 8 (missile)|Barak 8]] anti-air missiles, which are still in the final stages of completion with [[Israel Aerospace Industries]] and the [[Defence Research and Development Organisation]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Business Standard |url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/economy-policy/navy-s-wavering-delaying-warships-by-years-112082002026_1.html |title=Kolkotta class ships delayed |publisher=Business-standard.com |date=20 August 2012 |accessdate=20 August 2012}}</ref>
The ''Kolkata'' class are the largest destroyers ever to be constructed at Mazagon Docks, and as of 2013, all three ships of the class have been launched and are being fitted out.<ref name=ibnl1a10>{{cite news|title=India's 3rd naval destroyer launched|url=http://ibnlive.in.com/news/indias-3rd-indigenous-naval-destroyer-launched/112506-3.html|accessdate=20 July 2013|newspaper=IBN Live|date=1 April 2010}}</ref> Technical problems were found during the sea trials of the lead ship ''Kolkata'', which delayed the project by six months to early 2014.<ref name=it10j13 />
== Design and description == The ''Kolkata'' class share similar dimensions to the previous ''Delhi'' class, however they have 2,363 modifications which include major upgrades in weaponry, sensors and helicopter systems.<ref name=ajrn20a12>{{cite news|last1=Shukla|first1=Ajai|title=Dangerous consequences of warships built in India|url=http://www.rediff.com/news/report/dangerous-consequences-of-warships-built-in-india/20120820.htm|accessdate=9 June 2014|publisher=Rediff News|date=20 August 2012}}</ref> With a standard displacement of {{convert|6800|t|abbr=on}} and a full-load displacement of {{convert|7400|t|abbr=on}}, they are the largest destroyers ever operated by the Indian Navy.<ref name="INS Kolkata class"/> Some media reports have even given a full-load displacement of {{convert|7500|t|abbr=on}}.<ref name="hindujul14">{{cite news |title=Navy gets its largest destroyer|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/navy-gets-its-largest-destroyer/article6205050.ece |date=13 July 2014|accessdate=15 July 2014 |publisher=The Hindu}}</ref><ref name="defxprss">{{cite news |url=http://www.defenceexpress.com/index.php/navy/item/277-largest-destroyer-project-of-navy-hit-by-delay |title=Largest destroyer project of Navy hit by delay|publisher=Defence Express|date=6 Jun 2013|accessdate=15 July 2014}}</ref> These are the first stealth destroyers being built by India and marked a significant development in India's shipbuilding technology. The ships would incorporate modern weapons and sensors, and will have an advanced [[information warfare]] suite, an auxiliary control system with a sophisticated power distribution architecture, and modular crew quarters.<ref name=zn1a>{{cite news|title=INS Chennai adds to Naval might|url=http://zeenews.india.com/news/nation/ins-chennai-adds-to-naval-might_615908.html|accessdate=16 June 2013|newspaper=Zee News|date=1 April 2010}}</ref>
The class have a length of {{convert|163|m|ft|abbr=on}}, a [[Beam (nautical)|beam]] of {{convert|17.4|m|ft|abbr=on}} and a [[Draft (hull)|draught]] of {{convert|6.5|m|ft|abbr=on}}. The ship's power and propulsion features a standard [[Combined gas and gas]] system utilizing twin Zorya M36E gas turbine plants and four DT-59 reversible gas turbines. The class also features two KVM diesel engines. On-board Wartsila WCM-1000 generators and Kirloskar AC generators supply the ship's electricity. The two propellers are run via two RG-54 gearboxes. This configuration allows the ship to reach speeds in excess of {{convert|30|kn|abbr=on}}.<ref name=navaltechnology/><ref name=pib>{{cite web|title=Project 15-A destroyer, INS Kochi To be launched on 18 Sep 2009|url=http://www.pib.nic.in/newsite/erelease.aspx?relid=52673|publisher=PIB|accessdate=16 June 2013}}</ref> Aviation facilities include a large flight deck, which was re-designed to handle larger helicopters than the ''Delhi''-class, and an enclosed hangar for up to two maritime helicopters.<ref name=navaltechnology /><ref name=ajrn20a12/> [[File:ELM 2248 MF-STAR radar onboard INS Kolkata (D63) of the Indian Navy.png|thumbnail|left|The [[EL/M-2248 MF-STAR]] AESA is the primary radar of the ''Kolkata'' class]] The primary radar sensor of the class is the [[EL/M-2248 MF-STAR]] multi-mission [[Active electronically scanned array|AESA]].<ref name=sp8j14/><ref>{{cite news|title=IAI Delivers First of MF-STAR Radar System to a Foreign Customer|url=http://www.deagel.com/news/IAI-Delivers-First-of-MF-STAR-Radar-System-to-a-Foreign-Customer_n000007995.aspx|accessdate=20 July 2013|newspaper=Deagel|date=26 October 2010}}</ref><ref name=nt3n10>{{cite news|title=Indian Navy Receives First Israeli MR-STAR Radar|url=http://www.naval-technology.com/news/news100652.html|accessdate=20 July 2013|newspaper=Naval Technology|date=3 November 2010}}</ref> It is also equipped with [[Thales Nederland#Sensors|Thales LW-08]] long range volume search radar and [[EL/M-2238 STAR|EL/M-2238]] S-band STAR surveillance radar from [[Israel Aerospace Industries]]. A ''Nagin'' [[Towed array sonar|active towed array sonar]] and a bow-mounted sonar HUMSA-NG (hull-mounted sonar array - new generation) are carried for sub-surface surveillance. To protect against anti-ship missiles coming from multiple directions, the ship carries the [[Elbit Systems]] Deseaver MK-II decoy control and launching system.<ref name=navaltechnology/><ref name=ajrn20a12/>
The ship's main air-defence armament is composed of two 4x8-cell [[vertical launching system]]s (VLS) allowing for up to 32 [[Barak 8 (missile)|Barak 8]] (medium-long range) air-defence missiles.<ref name=NDTVKolkata/> In addition, four [[AK-630]] [[Close-in weapon system|CIWS]] are fitted for close-in defence.<ref name=navaltechnology/>
[[File:The Indian Navy destroyer INS Kolkata (D63) and the British Navy destroyer HMS Defender (D36) steam alongside the Ticonderoga-class guided-missile cruiser USS Antietam (CG 54) during an exercise.JPG|thumbnail|right| {{INS|Kolkata|D63|6}} and the British Royal Navy destroyer {{HMS|Defender|D36|6}} in the background during International Fleet Review 2016.]] The supersonic [[BrahMos]] anti-ship and land-attack missiles are the primary offensive armament of the ''Kolkata''-class.<ref name=it5m08>{{cite news|title=First test of BrahMos land-attack variant from the sea|url=http://brahmos.com/newscenter.php?newsid=60#|accessdate=17 July 2013|newspaper=India today|date=5 March 2008}}</ref> The BrahMos missiles are fitted into a 16-cell Universal Vertical Launcher Module (UVLM) allowing one missile per launch silo, and all 16 missiles can be fired in [[salvo]].<ref>{{cite news|title=BrahMos missile test-fired from warship INS Kolkata|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/BrahMos-missile-test-fired-from-warship-INS-Kolkata/articleshow/36295940.cms|accessdate=9 June 2014|publisher=The Times of India|date=9 June 2014}}</ref> Perhaps the most distinctive and noticeable armament of the ''Kolkata'' class is its {{convert|76|mm|abbr=on}} naval gun located forward of the bridge. The 76 mm gun provides limited anti-shipping capability and anti-air capability in addition to its naval gun fire-support role for land based operations.<ref name=navaltechnology/> For [[anti-submarine warfare]], the ''Kolkata''-class are equipped with a torpedo launching system via four torpedo tubes and two [[RBU-6000]] anti-submarine rocket launchers.<ref name=navaltechnology/><ref>{{cite web|title=Project 15-A Improved Delhi / VIshakhapattanam / DDGHM Kolkata|url=http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/world/india/d-project-15a.htm|publisher=Global Security|accessdate=16 June 2013}}</ref> BEL's Electronic Modular Command & Control Applications (EMCCA) Mk4 provides combat management.<ref name=sp8j14/>
Four million lines of codes have been written to develop the advanced combat management system onboard INS Kochi. The system is designed so that all the data about the surrounding threat comes in one place, along with analysis about the kind of threat. The system also advises the commanding officer about the kind of weaponry he should use to tackle the threat. Obviously, all this happens in real-time.<ref>{{cite web|title=INS Kochi is proof India good at integrating different systems on one platform|url=http://www.sundayguardianlive.com/news/1201-%E2%80%98ins-kochi-proof-india-good-integrating-different-systems-one-platform%E2%80%99|publisher=sunday guardian|accessdate=3 October 2015}}</ref> The Ship is equipped with sophisticated digital networks, such as Asynchronous Transfer Mode based Integrated Ship Data Network (AISDN), Combat Management System (CMS), Automatic Power Management System (APMS) and Auxiliary Control System (ACS). The AISDN is the information highway on which data from all the sensors and weapon ride. The CMS is used to integrate information from other platforms using indigenous data-link system, to provide Maritime Domain Awareness. The intricate power supply management is done using APMS, and remote control and monitoring of machinery is achieved through the ACS.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://indiannavy.nic.in/content/ins-kochi-commissioned-mumbai|title=INS Kochi commissioned at Mumbai {{!}} Indian Navy|website=indiannavy.nic.in|access-date=2016-05-05}}</ref>
==Ships of the class== [[File:INS Kolkata (D63) commissioning ceremony 5.JPG|thumb|INS ''Kolkata'' commissioning ceremony]]
Initially in 2008, the total program cost with long-term spare parts was expected to cost {{INRConvert|3800|c}},<ref>{{cite web|author=Ajai Shukla |url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/companies/world-class-warships-at-indian-prices-108041501011_1.html |title=World-class warships at Indian prices |publisher=Business-standard.com |date=15 April 2008 |accessdate=2 April 2010}}</ref> but the construction costs escalated about 225%, and by 2011, cost of the program became {{INRConvert|11662|c}}, with each ship costing {{INRConvert|3900|c}}.<ref>{{cite web|author=Ajai Shukla |url=http://ajaishukla.blogspot.in/2014/05/ins-kolkata-navys-most-powerful-warship.html |title=INS Kolkata, navy’s most powerful warship, to be delivered next month |publisher=Business-standard |date=2 May 2014 |accessdate=23 July 2014}}</ref> The [[Minister of Defence (India)|Defense Minister]] [[A. K. Antony]] cited the causes being the delay in supply of [[ABS Steels|warship-grade steel]] by Russia, increase in costs of Russian specialists due to inflation during the build period, wage revision due from October 2003 and delay in finalisation of cost of weapons and sensors.<ref name=stp5s11>{{cite news|title=Indian warships’ costs escalate over 225%|url=http://www.stratpost.com/indian-warships-costs-escalate-over-225|accessdate=20 July 2013|newspaper=StratPost|date=5 September 2011}}</ref><ref name=pib3a11>{{cite news|title=Delay in Indigenous Warship Projects of Navy|url=http://pib.nic.in/newsite/PrintRelease.aspx?relid=73820|accessdate=23 July 2013|newspaper=Press Information Bureau|date=3 August 2011}}</ref>
{|class="wikitable" |- !Name !Pennant !Yard No. !Builder !Laid Down !Launched !Sea Trials !Commissioned !Homeport !Status |- | {{INS|Kolkata|D63|6}} | D63 | 701<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.mazagondock.gov.in/newsite2010/pdf_doc/Annual_Reports/Annual_Report_English_2014-2015.pdf|title=MDL Annual Report|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> | rowspan=3|[[Mazagon Dock Limited]] | 27 March 2003 | 30 March 2006<ref>{{cite web|author=Reagan Gavin Rasquinha, TNN, 1 Apr 2006, 08.44pm IST |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/Cities/Bombay_Times/Queen_of_the_high_seas/articleshow/msid-1473297,curpg-1.cms |title=Queen of the high seas - Bombay Times - City |work= The Times of India |publisher=Timesofindia.indiatimes.com |date=1 April 2006 |accessdate=2 April 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hindu.com/2006/04/01/stories/2006040104971300.htm |title=National : A lethal combination of stealth and strength |work=The Hindu|date=1 April 2006 |accessdate=2 April 2010}}</ref> | 2013 | 16 August 2014<ref>http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/PM-Modi-inducts-Indias-largest-indigenously-built-warship-INS-Kolkata/articleshow/40313665.cms</ref> | rowspan="3" | [[Mumbai]] | Active |- | {{INS|Kochi||6}} | D64 | 702<ref name=":0" /> | 25 October 2005 | 18 September 2009<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.outlookindia.com/item.aspx?666275 |title=Mazagon Docks to Launch INS Kochi on Friday |publisher=News.outlookindia.com |accessdate=2 April 2010}}</ref> | 2014-15<ref name=asianage>{{cite news|last1=Parth Satam|title=INS Kochi to start sea trials in June|url=http://archive.asianage.com/mumbai/ins-kochi-start-sea-trials-june-246|accessdate=5 September 2014|work=Asian Age|date=10 April 2014}}</ref> | 30 September 2015<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.asianage.com/mumbai/trials-ins-kochi-be-sea-5-months-796 |title=Trials on, INS Kochi to be at sea in 5 months |publisher=Asian Age |accessdate=20 Feb 2015}}</ref> | Active |- | {{INS|Chennai||6}} | D65 | 702<ref name=":0" /> | 21 February 2006 | 1 April 2010<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://ibnlive.in.com/news/indias-3rd-indigenous-naval-destroyer-launched/112506-3.html |title=India's 3rd indigenous naval destroyer launched |publisher=Ibnlive.in.com |date=3 February 2010 |accessdate=2 April 2010}}</ref> | 2015-16 | 21 November 2016<ref>{{cite press release |url=https://www.indiannavy.nic.in/content/guided-missile-destroyer-ins-chennai-joins-indian-navy |title=Guided Missile Destroyer INS Chennai Joins the Indian Navy |publisher=Indian Navy |date=21 November 2016 |accessdate=21 November 2016}}</ref> | Active |- |}
